Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)

Utterance: Yeah, I started out doing magnetic resonance, studying things like bone and biomedical magnetic resonance.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Sekhar Ramanathan)
Utterance: Ended up playing with spins for a long time and the physics of spins just fascinated me.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Sekhar Ramanathan)
Utterance: So what do you think is a big difference between imaging large biological objects versus sensing very small quantum objects, I guess?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: In a way, it's part of the same continuum.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: What you're doing is changing the technological platform and you're actually able to probe it more sensitively.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: The resolution you're able to get is much higher, so you can see smaller signals in a much smaller volume.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Sekhar Ramanathan)
Utterance: How is the resolution higher?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: So it's because the nitrogen-vacancy center is a single defect.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: So you can actually see a single electron.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: In normal magnetic resonance, you don't have the sensitivity.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Sekhar Ramanathan)
Utterance: In order to be sensitive to like a single electron, do you have to be really close to it?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: You have to be close to it.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: You can detect it optically because if we tried to detect the magnetic moment of the electron, we wouldn't be able to do that because there, the energy is too low compared to thermal energies.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: But what the diamond system gives you is a natural up conversion in energy.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: So you can couple into an optical photon, which is then much easier to detect a single optical photon than it is to detect a micro wave.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Sekhar Ramanathan)
Utterance: Okay, I see.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: Yeah.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Sekhar Ramanathan)
Utterance: And that's why you're able to do it at room temperature as well.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: What are some of the challenges you face when trying to do quantum sensing with this platform?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: One of the key challenges, I think for all, any quantum technology is really understanding what limits your coherence times.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: And then the next question that comes up often is how do we make this better?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: So if I take a single qubit or a single spin, there's a certain limit up to its sensitivity.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: But if I can take entangled spins, in principle, I could make the system much more sensitive, but it usually comes at a cost 'cause when I entangle something, it's much more sensitive to de-coherence as well.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Sekhar Ramanathan)
Utterance: In a similar way, but maybe even in the opposite way where we want to figure out how to be as resilient from noise and all the kinds of noise sources.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Grad Student)
Utterance: Exactly.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Sekhar Ramanathan)

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Sekhar Ramanathan)
Utterance: The ones I do like, I call signal and that's an artificial definition that I'm making when I choose to build a sensor.
